awd_titl_txt: PIPP Phase I: Mobility Analysis for Pandemic Prevention Strategies (MAPPS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Infectious diseases naturally follow the movement of people. Once a transmissible disease emerges, human mobility and patterns of social mixing are largely responsible for its spread. Therefore, understanding patterns of human mobility and social interaction is essential for identifying the potential for pandemic spread.  This information is also critically important for developing science-based targeted interventions aimed at stopping or slowing the spread of a new pathogen. In addition, understanding how humans move across space and time and interact with each other has broad implications beyond pandemic prevention. This project will provide a framework to collect, capture, curate and analyze complex, multi-scale human movement and social interaction data that can be adapted to understand a wide variety of pressing problems including climate change, tracking of wildlife, disaster relief, management and urban planning. A fully functioning, accurate computational system for pandemic prediction could save millions of lives and billions of dollars in health care costs. 

With the establishment of the Center for Mobility Analysis for Pandemic Prevention Strategies (MAPPS) at Brown University, this project aims to: categorize, organize and synthesize existing data on mobility and social mixing; develop new and innovative tools for measuring mobility and social mixing; and use that information to develop and populate mathematical models aimed at predicting and preventing future pandemics.  Existing data on these issues will be systematically collected, catalogued and organized in a federated, publicly available database, while new data will be generated through targeted pilot projects. In addition, the project aims to develop a new device, possibly wearable, that is capable of measuring human mobility, social mixing and biometrics. The research team will develop a series of complex, flexible mathematical models that use these data to predict the emergence of new pandemics, describe epidemic dynamics, evaluate the effectiveness and impact of different intervention strategies, and inform health policy decisions for prevention and control.  The work will be infused with a strong focus on ethics and data privacy.  Focused, thematic workshops will bring together national and international experts with the aim of identifying innovative solutions to the technical and ethical issues raised by this project.  Finally, an integrative activity across the Brown University campus will serve as a template for similar data collection and analysis: the goals are to map the entire social network at the University, to use this information to better understand patterns of social mixing and to use that information to explore a variety of interventions that could potentially mitigate or eliminate pathogenic spread.  

This award is supported by the cross-directorate Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention Phase I (PIPP) program, which is jointly funded by the Directorates for Biological Sciences (BIO), Computer Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Engineering (ENG), and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic caused over 7 million confirmed deaths, 1.2  million of those in the United States. The true global death toll  likely rests in the tens of millions. During the height of the  pandemic, researchers placed renewed focus on the social and  environmental drivers of disease transmission. Of these, human  mobility and indoor environments commanded particular attention - mobility because of its role in generating the human  contact networks through which disease spreads, and indoor environments because airborne transmission made these sites of  explosive transmission events (instances of so-called  "superspreading").
  In the MAPPS (Mobility Analysis for Pandemic Prevention Strategies)  Project, we focused on understanding the unique opportunities and  challenges of measuring human mobility at the local level, as a  prelude to a feasibility study (MAPPING@Brown) in which we sought to  measure mobility networks across Brown University.
  The MAPPS Workshop: In January 2023, we organized a  multidisciplinary workshop attended by researchers from institutions  around the country. Epidemiologists, computer scientists, network  scientists, philosophers, and others attended the workshop to discuss  methodological, technological, and privacy-related challenges  associated with mobility measurement. Presentations summarized  possible technologies (e..g, Bluetooth, GPS), privacy-preserving  methods for social network data, and the role of network science in  epidemiologic modeling of infectious disease outbreaks. Small working  groups aided us in identifying major practical and scientific goals,  as well as priorities for soliciting feedback from potential study  participants to address concerns regarding the use and protection of  their location data. After the workshop, we produced a comprehensive  report of the proceedings and incorporated attendees' insights into  the design of MAPPING@Brown, not least of which involved focusing our  data collection on the indoor environment. Thereafter, we planned a  large-scale study of indoor movement in the Brown School of Public  Health (SPH).
  Focus Groups: In the months leading up to the MAPPING@Brown Study,  we conducted a series of focus groups with SPH students, faculty, and  staff to gauge their interest our project's aims and to understand  their concerns regarding our use and collection of high-resolution  location data within the building. Through these focus groups we  gathered crucial information about how different groups perceived  attempts to collect these data and the extent of their privacy  concerns. This feedback informed both the scope and modes of data  collection we pursued during the study, and motivated us to develop  strict guidelines and procedures for handling sensitive participant  data.
  Smartphone App: We developed a smartphone application for iPhone and  Android devices. This application was designed to scan for Low-Energy  Bluetooth (BLE) signals from a network of BLE transmitters we would  deploy throughout the SPH building, and upload information regarding  each observed signal (e.g., timestamp, signal strength) to a secure  external database. The application also reported information regarding  the Brown WiFi access point to which a phone was connected at the time  of a BLE observation. We would use this application as our primary  means of data collection during the MAPPING@Brown study.
  MAPPING@Brown Study: In November 2023, we conducted the  MAPPING@Brown Study. Participants completed a survey with questions on  demographics, employment, and typical smartphone use and downloaded  the smartphone app upon enrolling the study. We deployed over 2,000  BLE transmitters throughout 8 floors of the Brown SPH building. In  all, we captured over 130 million BLE and 2 million WiFi reports from  the smartphones of 122 individuals during a two-week period. To our  knowledge, this was the largest study using BLE as a source of a  high-resolution location data.
  We plan to use data from this feasibility study to estimate  individuals' locations throughout the course of the study and to use  these estimates to understand how contact networks evolved during the  study. In future work, we will develop statistical and computational  tools to process and analyze these data, incorporate them into  simulation models of infectious disease spread, and design future  localization studies tailored to other indoor environments.


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Mark Nathan Lurie
por.por_txt_cntn:
The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic caused over 7 million confirmed deaths, 1.2 million of those in the United States. The true global death toll likely rests in the tens of millions. During the height of the pandemic, researchers placed renewed focus on the social and environmental drivers of disease transmission. Of these, human mobility and indoor environments commanded particular attention - mobility because of its role in generating the human contact networks through which disease spreads, and indoor environments because airborne transmission made these sites of explosive transmission events (instances of so-called "superspreading").
 In the MAPPS (Mobility Analysis for Pandemic Prevention Strategies) Project, we focused on understanding the unique opportunities and challenges of measuring human mobility at the local level, as a prelude to a feasibility study (MAPPING@Brown) in which we sought to measure mobility networks across Brown University.
 The MAPPS Workshop: In January 2023, we organized a multidisciplinary workshop attended by researchers from institutions around the country. Epidemiologists, computer scientists, network scientists, philosophers, and others attended the workshop to discuss methodological, technological, and privacy-related challenges associated with mobility measurement. Presentations summarized possible technologies (e..g, Bluetooth, GPS), privacy-preserving methods for social network data, and the role of network science in epidemiologic modeling of infectious disease outbreaks. Small working groups aided us in identifying major practical and scientific goals, as well as priorities for soliciting feedback from potential study participants to address concerns regarding the use and protection of their location data. After the workshop, we produced a comprehensive report of the proceedings and incorporated attendees' insights into the design of MAPPING@Brown, not least of which involved focusing our data collection on the indoor environment. Thereafter, we planned a large-scale study of indoor movement in the Brown School of Public Health (SPH).
 Focus Groups: In the months leading up to the MAPPING@Brown Study, we conducted a series of focus groups with SPH students, faculty, and staff to gauge their interest our project's aims and to understand their concerns regarding our use and collection of high-resolution location data within the building. Through these focus groups we gathered crucial information about how different groups perceived attempts to collect these data and the extent of their privacy concerns. This feedback informed both the scope and modes of data collection we pursued during the study, and motivated us to develop strict guidelines and procedures for handling sensitive participant data.
 Smartphone App: We developed a smartphone application for iPhone and Android devices. This application was designed to scan for Low-Energy Bluetooth (BLE) signals from a network of BLE transmitters we would deploy throughout the SPH building, and upload information regarding each observed signal (e.g., timestamp, signal strength) to a secure external database. The application also reported information regarding the Brown WiFi access point to which a phone was connected at the time of a BLE observation. We would use this application as our primary means of data collection during the MAPPING@Brown study.
 MAPPING@Brown Study: In November 2023, we conducted the MAPPING@Brown Study. Participants completed a survey with questions on demographics, employment, and typical smartphone use and downloaded the smartphone app upon enrolling the study. We deployed over 2,000 BLE transmitters throughout 8 floors of the Brown SPH building. In all, we captured over 130 million BLE and 2 million WiFi reports from the smartphones of 122 individuals during a two-week period. To our knowledge, this was the largest study using BLE as a source of a high-resolution location data.
 We plan to use data from this feasibility study to estimate individuals' locations throughout the course of the study and to use these estimates to understand how contact networks evolved during the study. In future work, we will develop statistical and computational tools to process and analyze these data, incorporate them into simulation models of infectious disease spread, and design future localization studies tailored to other indoor environments.
